sen.j: 後西天皇（ごさい てんのう、寛永14年11月16日（1638年1月1日） - 貞享2年2月22日（1685年3月26日）、在位：承応3年11月28日（1655年1月5日） - 寛文3年1月26日（1663年3月5日））は、江戸時代の第111代天皇。
sen.e: Emperor Gosai (January 1st, 1638 - March 26th 1685), his reign was January 5th, 1655 - March 5th, 1663, he was the 111th Emperor during Edo period.
Emperor Gosai (January 1, 1638 - March 26, 1685), the 111th Emperor, reigned during the Edo period (from January 5, 1655 to March 5, 1663).

sen.e: His mother was Chujo of the Left, 櫛笥隆致's daughter, Go-Mizunoo Nashi no suke (a court lady of the first rank), Hoshun mon in Takako KUSHIGE.

sen.cmt: Takashi KUSHIGEとしました。左中将の補足をしました。

sen.j: はじめ高松宮初代好仁親王の王女を娶って高松宮第二代を継承して花町宮（花町院）（はなまちのみや）と号した。
sen.e: Firstly the Emperor named Hanamachi no miya (Hanamachi no miya in) to succeed the second Takamatsu no Miya, named after the first Takamatsu no Miya Princess.

First, the Emperor was named Hanamachinomiya (Hanamachiin) to succeed the second Takamatsunomiya, after marrying the princess of Imperial Prince Yoshihito, who was the first Takamatsunomiya.
sen.cmt: 高松宮初代好仁親王の王女を娶って を、after marrying the princess of the first Takamatsunomiya としました。

sen.j: 即位の前年には兄である後光明天皇の名代として江戸に下っている。
sen.e: The year before the enthronement, he came to Edo to to act as his older brother's proxy.
The year before the enthronement, he came to Edo to act as a proxy for his older brother.
The year before the enthronement, he came to Edo to act as a proxy for his older brother, Emperor Gokomyo.
sen.cmt: 後光明 を追加しました。

sen.j: 後光明天皇が崩御した時、同帝の養子になっていた実弟識仁親王（霊元天皇）はまだ生後間もなく他の兄弟は全て出家の身であったために、識仁親王が成長し即位するまでの繋ぎとして、1654年（承応3年）11月28日に即位。
sen.e: When Emperor Go-Komyo died, his adopted son and his younger brother, Prince Satohito (the Emperor Go-Komyo) was just after born, and other brothers are all in religion, Emperor Gosai enthroned on November 28th, 1654 until Prince Satohito was old enough to succeed the throne.

When Emperor Go-Komyo died, his adopted son and younger brother, Prince Satohito (the Emperor Go-Komyo) had just been born, and the other brothers were all living the religious life, Emperor Gosai was enthroned on November 28, 1654 until Prince Satohito was old enough to succeed to the throne.

When Emperor Gokomyo died, his adopted son and younger brother, Imperial Prince Satohito (the Emperor Reigen) had just been born, and the other brothers were all living the religious life, Emperor Gosai was enthroned on November 28, 1654 until Imperial Prince Satohito was old enough to succeed to the throne.
sen.cmt: 名前を修正 しました。 Imperial Princeとしました。

sen.j: 1663年（寛文3年）1月26日、10歳に成長した識仁親王に譲位。
sen.e: On January 26th, 1663, Emperor Gosai abdicated and passed the position to Prince Satohito who turned ten years old.
On January 26, 1663, Emperor Gosai abdicated and passed the position to Prince Satohito, who had turned 10 years old.
On January 26, 1663, Emperor Gosai abdicated and passed the position to Imperial Prince Satohito, who had turned ten years old.
sen.cmt: Imperial Princeとしました。数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.e: He mainly threw himself into studies and left many books such as "水日集".

sen.e: He was a talented poet and had deep understanding of classic studies.

sen.j: 治世中には伊勢神宮・大坂城・内裏などの炎上や明暦の大火、地方の地震、水害などが多発したため、当時の人々は天皇の不徳を責めたと言う。
sen.e: During his reign Ise-jingu Shrine, Osaka-jo Castle and the Imperial Palace were burnt down, also there was a Great Fire in Meireki,or the earthquake in country area and flooding occurred, it is said people in those days criticized the Emperor for being immoral.
sen.cmt: 明暦の大火→Great Fire in Meireki [定訳不明]
sen.e: During his reign, Ise-jingu Shrine, Osaka-jo Castle and the Imperial Palace were burned down; additionally, there was a great fire in Meireki, an earthquake in a rural area and the occurrence of flooding; moreover, it is said that people in those days criticized the Emperor as being immoral.

During his reign, Ise-jingu Shrine, Osaka-jo Castle and the Imperial Palace were burned down; additionally, there was a great fire in Meireki, or an earthquake in a rural area and the occurrence of flooding; therefore it is said that people in those days criticized the Emperor as being immoral.

sen.j: もっとも、識仁親王の早期即位を望む後水尾法皇と有力外様大名（仙台藩）の従兄弟という天皇の血筋を嫌った江戸幕府双方の意向の一致が天皇の早期退位を志向し、それが「天皇不徳説」の根底にあったとの見方もある。
sen.e: There is another theory that the Emperor was said to be immoral as there was the background of Emperor Go-Mizunoo wished Prince Satohito's early enthronement, and Edo government did not like the Emperor Gosai's family line being cousin of strong outside daimyo (Sendai clan), both parties made Emperor's early abdication happen.

There is another theory that the Emperor was said to be immoral, given the fact that Emperor Go-Mizunoo wanted Prince Satohito's early enthronement and because the Edo government didn't approve of the Emperor Gosai's family line being the cousin to a strong outside daimyo (the Sendai clan), whereupon both parties caused the Emperor's early abdication to take place.

There is another theory that the Emperor was said to be immoral, given the fact that Cloistered Emperor Gomizunoo wanted Imperial Prince Satohito's early enthronement and because the Edo government didn't approve of the Emperor Gosai's family line being the cousin to a strong outside daimyo (the Sendai clan), whereupon both parties caused the Emperor's early abdication to take place.
sen.cmt: Imperial Prince Satohito, Cloistered Emperor Gomizunooとしました。

sen.e: Emperor Gosai enthroned between his brother in law and nephew, he himself could not leave his family line for Imperial succession.

sen.j: そのため、同じような道をたどった第53代淳和天皇の別名「西院天皇」の「西院」にちなみ、「後西院」と追号された。
sen.e: He received the posthumous name of 'Gosai in', named after 'Sai in', different name of the 53rd Emperor, Emperor Junna, 'the Emperor Saiin' who had a similar background.

He received the posthumous name of 'Gosaiin,' named after 'Saiin,' a different name for the fifty-third Emperor, Junna, given that 'the Emperor Saiin' had a similar background.

sen.j: 明治以後、天皇号の復活にともない「後西院天皇」と呼ばれたが、大正14年（1925年）院号が廃され「後西天皇」となった。
sen.e: After Meiji period, with the restoration of Tenno go, he was called 'Emperor Gosai in', the in title was abolished in 1925 and he was called 'Emperor Gosai'.
After the Meiji period, with the restoration of Tenno go, he was called 'Emperor Gosai in,' though the suffix "in" was abolished in 1925 and he was subsequently called 'Emperor Gosai."
After the Meiji period, with the restoration of Tenno go, he was called 'Emperor Gosaiin,' but the suffix "in" was abolished in 1925 and he was subsequently called 'Emperor Gosai.'

sen.j: ただし、「西院」をもって一つの語なのであるから、後西では意味が通じなくなるので、他の太上天皇の院号と同一視して院を除くのではなく、後西院天皇と称するべきであるとする歴史学者も多い。
sen.e: However some historians mentioned as 'sai in ' is one word, it does not make sense separating 'sai in' and 'gosai', so his name should be 'Emperor Gosaiin instead of following same way as other In go of ex-emperors.

However, some historians have used 'sai in ' as one word, saying it would make no sense to separate 'sai in' and 'gosai,' so his name should be 'Emperor Gosaiin' instead of following same way as the other 'In go' of ex-emperors.

However, many historians say that his name should be Emperor Gosaiin and should not remove the suffix "in" like other names of retired emperors as 'Saiin' should be used as one word; they say it would make no sense with only "Gosai."
sen.cmt: retired emperorsとしました。より原文に近くなるように修正しました。
